title: A Pilot, Multiple Crossover, Randomized Block Sequence, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial for Use of Methylphenidate for Cognitive and Behavioral Symptoms in Mild Cognitive Impairment and Dementia
description_brief:
Investigators are doing this research study to find out if methylphenidate (MPH) can help people with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) or mild dementia likely due to Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and related disorders (ADRD).

The study drug MPH is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), but MPH is not approved by the FDA to treat Mild Cognitive Impairment or mild dementia related to Alzheimer's Disease. However, other studies have been done in which MPH has been given to people with neurodegenerative dementias and results have shown some improvement in these people's mood and cognition. Investigators would like to see if MPH will help mood and cognition.

This study will take place completely virtually (with the option to come in for the first visit to meet the study team). All study visits will occur over a secure videoconferencing platform. All study materials will be shipped directly to the home of each participant.
description_detailed:
Investigators will give participants a supply of study drug. Participants will take the study drug by mouth once a day for 16 weeks. It is important for participants to follow our instructions about how to take the study drug. Participants can take the drug with or without food. Investigators will provide enough study drug for participants to take until the next visit.

For this study, there are 3 blocks: each month-long block will consist of MPH for a two-week period (I.e. "A" Blocks 1, 2, 3) and PBO for a two-week period (I.e. "B" Blocks 1, 2, 3) in random assignment order for each block. Thus, all volunteers will receive a four-week PBO-lead in and acclimatization followed by treatment with MPH or matching PBO for eight-weeks each in three randomized sequence crossover blocks for a total of 10 weeks of PBO and 6 weeks of MPH.

Weekly Tasks During the study, certain tasks must be done each week.

Every Day:

The following tasks must be done each day throughout the study:

* Wear the activity tracker
* Take study medication

Six Days per Week:

The following tasks will be completed six days per week:

* Complete online cognitive games

  o Use online brain games to rate daily mood and sleep quality
* Synchronize Fitness tracker to study provided tablet (if requested)

Once every five days:

The following activities must be done approximately every five days throughout the trial:

• Charge Fitness tracker during a time when the subject is resting but not sleeping

The study coordinator will periodically log into both the Fitness tracker dashboard and the online brain game account to check the battery level of the Fitness tracker, ensure the Fitness tracker is synching to the Fitness tracker dashboard, and monitor the completion of cognitive exercises.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: 11 Participants signed consent and enrolled. 3 Screen failed and 1 Withdrew due to study non compliance, prior to assignment to groups. 7 participants proceeded to assignment and Block 1A.

groups.title: Experimental: Sequence 1:MPH, PBO, MPH, PBO, PBO, MPH
groups.description:
Experimental: Sequence 1:MPH, PBO, MPH, PBO, PBO, MPH

Over the 16-week study, each participant moved through four, 4-week treatment periods: a Placebo (PBO) lead-in, acclimation period followed by three, crossover Methylphenidate (MPH) vs PBO "blocks". Each "block" consisted of treatment with MPH for two-weeks and treatment with PBO for two-weeks; each block order will be randomly assigned. In this group, participants first received Methylphenidate (MPH) for 2 weeks, then placebo for 2 weeks, then MPH for 2 weeks, then Placebo for 2 weeks, then Placebo for 2 weeks, then MPH for 2 weeks.

groups.title: Experimental: Sequence 2:MPH, PBO, PBO, MPH, MPH, PBO

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: Participants were analyzed in treatment/placebo groups based on randomized crossover assignment.

groups.title: Randomized Crossover Methylphenidate/Placebo
groups.description:
During this study, participants will get both the study drug Methylphenidate Extended Release Capsule and the placebo in random order. Placebo is being used in this study to compare to see if any improvements in cognition other areas are due to the study drug or due to other reasons.

Methylphenidate Extended Release Oral Capsule: Stimulant It can treat ADHD and narcolepsy.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Feasibility of a Virtual Multicrossover Randomized Control Trial Design as Measured my Completion Rates and Medication Compliance.
outcomeMeasures.description: To assess feasibility of this study design, completion rates of all study tasks and medication dosing will be evaluated. Benchmark goals for feasibility measures are set as follows: retain \>80% of participants enrolled, observe \>80% medication adherence, and \>80% outcome assessment completion rates.

groups.title: All Study Participants
groups.description:
During this study, participants will get both the study drug Methylphenidate Extended Release Capsule and the placebo in random order.

For this study, there are 3 blocks: each month-long block will consist of MPH for a two-week period (I.e. Blocks 1a, 2a, 3a) and PBO for a two-week period (I.e. Blocks 1b, 2b, 3b) in random assignment order for each block. Thus, all volunteers will receive a four-week PBO-lead in and acclimatization followed by treatment with MPH or matching PBO for eight-weeks each in three randomized sequence crossover blocks for a total of 10 weeks of PBO and 6 weeks of MPH.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognition as Measured by the Repeatable Battery for the Assessment Neuropsychological Status-Update (RBANS)
outcomeMeasures.description: This study is investigating the effects of methylphenidate to see if it will help improve cognition in adults with Alzheimer's Disease. RBANS scores range from 40 to 160 with higher scores indicating higher cognitive functioning.

groups.title: Study Participants on MPH Treatment
groups.description: Study Participants on MPH Treatment Blocks

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognition as Measured by Daily, Home-based Brain Games (Lumosity, Lumos Labs, Inc.)
outcomeMeasures.description: This study is investigating the effects of methylphenidate to see if it will help improve cognition in adults with Alzheimer's Disease using daily Lumosity brain games. The range of possible Lumosity scores varies, but higher scores indicate better game performance. LPI (Lumosity Performance Index) is a standardized performance metric that shows how well you are performing on Lumosity games and lets you compare performance across games and Cognitive Areas. Cognitive LPI is calculated using a weighted average of the Game LPIs from all Cognitive Areas. LPI: The low score is 0, the high score is 2000. Average is 1000.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: 6 participants played Lumosity games. LPI values for all 12 games were averaged into an LPI Composite Score for each participant in each treatment phase (MPH or PBO) in each block (1,2,3), then averaged the LPI composites for each treatment condition (MPH or PBO) for each individual, and then averaged the individuals for each treatment condition and got the standard deviation.

outcomeMeasures.title: Sleep as Measured by Fitbit Charge 3
outcomeMeasures.description: This study is investigating whether treatment with methylphenidate affects sleep levels. Methylphenidate may increase daily activity or affect the amount or quality of sleep.

explanation_target: Reason: The investigational drug is methylphenidate (MPH), a central nervous system stimulant that blocks reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine (increasing catecholaminergic tone) and is FDA‑approved for ADHD — i.e., a symptomatic, pro‑attentional/motivational agent rather than a therapy targeting Alzheimer pathology. citeturn1search0turn1search3

Act (evidence): MPH has been tested in randomized trials in people with Alzheimer disease for apathy and related behavioral symptoms (e.g., the ADMET/ADMET2 trials) and showed improvement in apathy/neuropsychiatric symptoms though not disease modification; cognition effects are variable. This trial’s stated aim (“help mood and cognition” and title referencing cognitive and behavioral symptoms) fits a symptomatic cognitive/behavioral enhancer approach. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Reflect: Classification choice — 'Cognitive enhancer' — is based on (1) MPH’s mechanism (catecholamine reuptake blockade) and (2) the trial’s intent to improve cognition/mood rather than to modify Alzheimer’s pathology (amyloid/tau). The intervention is a small‑molecule stimulant used symptomatically, not a biologic or a disease‑targeted anti‑amyloid/tau agent. Note: there is overlap — MPH is also used to treat neuropsychiatric symptoms (apathy) in AD, so one could reasonably emphasize "neuropsychiatric symptom improvement" as a secondary category depending on the trial’s primary outcome. citeturn1search0turn0search1
Web search results used: StatPearls summary of methylphenidate mechanism and properties (mechanism: blocks DAT/NAT). citeturn1search0

Web search results used: FDA communications and labeling updates describing methylphenidate and other stimulants as treatments for ADHD (supports that MPH is an approved stimulant, not a disease‑modifying AD therapy). citeturn1search3

Web search results used: ADMET / ADMET2 randomized trials showing methylphenidate produced improvements in apathy/neuropsychiatric measures in Alzheimer disease cohorts (supports symptomatic use in dementia). citeturn0search1turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug is methylphenidate, a central nervous system stimulant that blocks the dopamine transporter (DAT) and norepinephrine transporter (NET), increasing synaptic dopamine and norepinephrine and producing symptomatic pro‑attentional/motivational effects rather than targeting Alzheimer pathology. citeturn1search0turn1search6

Act: The trial tests methylphenidate for cognitive and behavioral symptoms (a symptomatic cognitive enhancer/apathy treatment). Prior randomized trials in Alzheimer disease (ADMET / ADMET2) showed improvement in apathy/neuropsychiatric measures but no evidence of disease modification, supporting a neurotransmitter‑modulation symptomatic approach rather than anti‑amyloid/tau or other disease‑modifying mechanisms. Based on the drug’s mechanism (DAT/NET blockade) and the trial intent, assign CADRO category D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search1turn0search0turn1search0

Reflect: Classification check — CADRO D (Neurotransmitter Receptors) best matches because methylphenidate acts on monoaminergic neurotransmission (dopamine/norepinephrine transporters/receptors) to produce symptomatic cognitive/behavioral effects. It is not directed at amyloid, tau, inflammation, vasculature, or other core AD pathologies, nor is it a multi‑target disease‑modifying biologic, so D is the most specific appropriate category. citeturn1search0turn0search1

Web search results used (supporting evidence): (1) StatPearls entry on methylphenidate: mechanism = blocks reuptake/transporters for dopamine and norepinephrine. citeturn1search0 (2) Review on stimulants / methylphenidate effects on catecholaminergic systems. citeturn1search6 (3) ADMET / ADMET2 randomized trials showing methylphenidate improved apathy in AD (symptomatic benefit). citeturn0search1turn0search0 (4) FDA communications and labeling context for stimulants (class indication and safety updates). citeturn0search6
